loans.name: Paulo

texts.en: Paulo is a 38-year-old married man with one child living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He operates a guest house and at the same time has a restaurant and bar business. He is faced with challenges of low capital that hinder progress of his business. Despite that, he hopes to have a good business that can fetch him more income. He has asked for a loan to help him buy food and drinks for his hotel business.

loans.use: to buy food and drinks for his hotel business.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is an intelligent and very resourceful 46-year-old smallholder farmer. She has defied the notion among her friends that farming is an old-fashioned way of earning a living. Her primary sources of income are milk, eggs and farming. Lucy hails from Chuka, Kenya, an area that enjoys favorable weather patterns and this boosts crop production in the area. Lucy, being someone who is very ambitious and someone who always takes advantage of positive things, would like to capitalize on the good weather patterns experienced in the region and boost her farming. Being a hardworking mother, Lucy has always ensured that she puts food on the table for her family. She also ensures she is able to take her children to school.

Lucy detests living in conditions of poverty and she has a plan to improve her standard of living. This is why she is seeking a loan of 41,600 KES in order to be able to purchase a dairy cow. This will help in producing milk and manure to be used on her farm. Milk from the cow will be sold to the local market and this means improved cash flow. Through improved cash flow this means that profits will be higher and she can comfortably take care of her family and take her kids to school. Through your loan Lucy will be empowered economically and be able to improve her standard of living and also those of people living within the area. Lucy is very comfortable with the repayment plan and the monthly installments.

loans.use: To buy an additional dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to add to his savings and buy many cases of beer and lemonade to resell and earn more

loans.name: Primitive

texts.en:
Primitive is 39 years old. She is married with four children aged between 4 and 16 years old, three of whom go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 20 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children and to improve her savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy many cases of beer to resell

loans.name: Mohamed M.

texts.en:
This is Mohamed M. He is single with no children. He has one dependent, who lives with him for medical attention.

In 2000, Mohamed M. established his ready-made clothing business, where he sells jeans, tights, and dresses, etc. Working six days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about SLL 6,303,000 every month from this business.

He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. He has already received and successfully repaid one loan and now requires a new loan in order to buy dozens of ladies' jeans, dresses, tights, blouses, etc.

In the future, Mohamed M. plans to rent a shop, reinvest in and expand the business. His previous plan was met by opening another outlet. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy dozens of ladies' jeans, dresses, tights, blouses, etc.

loans.name: Febie

texts.en:
Febie, a 48-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines, operates a "buko" business (more commonly known as a coconut business). She is married to Reynaldo and together they manage their own household while operating the buko business. In addition to this, Febie also sells charcoal which she packs in plastic. They are working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and to always meet the needs of their children who are all still at school.

Febie buys coconut fruit that is native to the Philippines and which is grown mostly in the South Region of Luzon. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 25,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more coconuts to expand her product inventory and also to purchase additional sacks of charcoal. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Febie hopes that their business will continue to operate and that their profit will increase more. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more coconuts and sacks of charcoal she sells.

loans.name: Boaz

texts.en:
Boaz is a 50 year old father of three, whose children are aged between 23 and 18 years old. He lives with his family in Mbarara town, but is originally from Isingiro in Western Uganda. 

Boaz started out in business as an entrepreneur selling essential commodities in his grocery store. Having finished junior high school, he later went on to acquire a diploma in Business. Noticing the plight of children in his community who were orphaned due to AIDS, he founded a Non-Government Organization (NGO) aimed at empowering AIDS affected families and other vulnerable households to live a better life. 

Through his community development projects, he realized that there was a need for life changing technologies in the most vulnerable households to enable them live a better life. With this in mind, he started researching and collaborating with social enterprises that had a component of social responsibility in the areas of clean energy, environment conservation plus food and nutrition security. Through this research he built partnerships with solar and improved cook stoves distribution companies. While doing this, he was introduced to the improved cook stove business, having visited the UpEnergy stall, during an energy exhibition week. Realizing that product demand was high, and that he enjoyed selling energy-efficient stoves a lot, Boaz decided to become an UpEnergy distribution partner as well. He went on to register a social enterprise that enables local communities gain access to life changing technologies. And ever since then, he has been successfully selling UpEnergy products for the last four years. He attributes his success to the healthy margins and the ability to acquire small volumes of products on consignment from UpEnergy, a reason why he appreciates the well managed operations at UpEnergy. 

Aside from earning a living through product sales, for Boaz the life changing testimonies and experience of the women who have been able to switch from using hazardous methods of cooking and lighting, makes him feel proud of not only himself, but his entire community. He is also proud to be able to improve the livelihoods of people in the communities who are able to save from improved fuel use. These savings are being channeled to other expenses like school fees for children and housing expenses. His aspiration is to set up an energy center where people in his community will be able to access information on energy related products and environmental conservation. He also aspires to have more energy product distribution and stocking points in the western part of the country. The loan will enable Boaz to scale up his business and allow him to increase stock, so that he saves time and transportation costs by not having to travel as often to replenish stock in order to meet the high demand for stoves. A portion of the loan will also go towards leasing a tricycle that will make it easy for him to reach rural communities and reduce transportation costs that currently eat up most of his margins.

loans.use: To pay for products, such as improved cook stoves, and lease a tricycle for transportation.

loans.name: Cfjdt 4 Group

texts.fr: CFJDT 4 est un sous groupe de la Convergence des Femmes et Jeunes pour le Développement de Tassette. Il est composé de femmes et d'hommes qui sont tous dans le même secteur de travail et qui habitent le même village . La présidente AIDA est une femme qui habite dans le même village et se reconnait par la main levée sur la phot. Elle est marié et a un parent bénéficiaire dans l'institution. Elle évolue dans la commercialisation des poissons et crustacés. Elle sollicite ce montant pour aller sur la petite cote, acheter des poissons fraiches, fumées et séchés ainsi que des produits de mer pour les revendre au marché central de la ville . Elle aide son mari dans la gestion des dépenses quotidiennes et les frais de scolarité de ses enfants. Elle commence sa journée à 8h pour la terminer à 18h. Elle a une expérience de plus de 4 ans dans cette activité. A l'avenir, elle souhaite avec l'aide de l'institution augmenter ses revenus en diversifiant ses produits et épargner de l'argent à coté. Elle voudrait aussi ouvrir une boutique d'alimentation générale dans le même marché de la ville .
texts.en:
CFJDT 4 is a subgroup of “La Convergence des Femmes et Jeunes pour le Développement de Tassette” (The Convergence of Women and Youth for the Development of Tassette). It is composed of women and men who are all the same sector of work and who live in the same village. 

The President, Aida, is a woman who lives in the same village and is recognizable by the raised hand in the photo. She is married and has a beneficiary parent in the institution. She operates in the commercialization of fish and crustaceans. She requests this amount to go the small shore to buy fresh, smoked, and dried fish, as well as seafood to resell them at the central market of the city. 

She helps her husband in managing the daily expenses and the school fees of her children. She begins her day at 8am and finishes it at 6pm. She has more than 4 years of experience in this activity. In the future, with help from the institution, she hopes to increase her income by diversifying her products and to set money aside. She would also like to open a general food shop in the same market of the city.

loans.use: to buy fresh and dried fish and some crustaceans and then resell them

loans.name: Ruben Arturo

texts.es: Rubén de 32 años de edad habita en vivienda propia junto a su grupo familiar desde hace 4 años, por lo que se siente feliz pero desea mejorar más su vivienda. Él se desempeña como jornalero en una finca cercana desde hace muchos años, y es en ese trabajo que se apoya para salir adelante y apoyar con los gastos económicos de su hogar. Rubén desea adquirir un crédito con FUSAI el cual le permita invertir en: lámina galvanizada, madera y clavos para ampliar su vivienda y de esta manera mejorar la calidad de vida con la que cuenta actualmente, ya que siente que viven en hacinamiento.
texts.en: Rubén is 32 years old and has lived in his own house with his family for 4 years. Which makes him happy but he wants to make improvements on his house. He has worked as labor on a nearby farm for many years and this work helps him to get ahead and help with the household expenses. Rubén wants to get a loan from FUSAI which he will invest in galvanized laminate, wood and nails to expand his house and in this way improve the quality of living that he currents enjoys as he feels they are overcrowded.

loans.use: to invest in galvanized laminate, wood and nails to expand his house.

loans.name: Famille Rubambiza Group

texts.fr: Busirimu vit dans un milieu où la culture du café a fait des agriculteurs des hommes de valeur, raison pour laquelle il a été motivé de les planter dans son champ. Il craint les maladies de plantes et les marchés d'écoulement incertains mais il s'estimerait heureux s'il disposait d'une étendue suffisante de culture, remplacerait les vieux tiges par des jeunes plants car cela leur permettrait d'avoir une bonne récolte et vivre  dans des conditions acceptables avec sa famille. Il est accompagné de son épouse sur la photo.
texts.en: Growing coffee has proved profitable for the farmers who do it in Busirimu's village.  This is why he decided to plant coffee in his field.  He is concerned about possible plant diseases and difficulties with the end market, but he considers himself happy to be able to plant enough of the crop and replace old plants with new, more fruitful plants.  This ensures a good crop and allows him to provide good living conditions for his family.  Busirimu is seen in the photo with his wife.

loans.use: to pay for tending and harvesting the coffee crop.

loans.name: Cesiri Group

texts.fr:
Mamadou est celui qui  tient la corde du bœuf sur la photo.
Mamadou est  un malien  non scolarisé. Il est âgé de  38 ans, marié Père de 06 enfants, âgés de 4 à 17ans dont 3 sont scolarisés. Sa femme fait le  stockage de céréales. 
 Mamadou fait  l’embouche bovine,Il prend le prêt avec le RMCR pour acheter   beaucoup d’aliments bétails (tourteau, sel, du son de mil) pour nourrir ses bœufs. Il s’approvisionne  dans  les foires environnantes  et revend  les bœufs dans un pays voisin(R.C.I).Il a une expérience de 5 ans  d’activité.
Dans ses ventes, il gagne en moyenne 20000 FCFA de profit par Bœuf, Avec le profit,  Mamadou  pourra subvenir aux besoins de sa famille (habillement, santé et frais de scolarité).  Il est souvent confronté à des   difficultés de traversé des frontières et aux couts chers des frais de transport des bœufs mais organise généralement  le voyage avec certains  emboucheurs  de sa localité pour relever les défis.
Dans l’avenir  Mamadou veut un prêt beaucoup plus  élevé pour développer son activité d’embouche pour gagner plus de profit afin de s’acheter un terrain en ville à usage d’habitation puis le construire pour sa  famille.
texts.en:
Mamadou is the person in the photo who is holding the rope on the cow. 

Mamadou is a citizen of Mali who has not attended school. He is 38 years old, married, and the father of six children, aged between 4 and 17, of whom three are attending school. His wife warehouses grain for resale. 

 Mamadou raises cattle. He is taking out the loan with RMCR to buy a lot of cattle feed (feed cakes, salt, millet bran) to feed his cattle. He stocks up at nearby weekly markets and resells the cattle in a neighborhing country (R.C.I.) He has five years of experience in this business. 

In his sales, he earns on average 20,000 F CFA of profit per head of cattle. With the profit Mamadou can cater for his family's needs (clothing, healthcare, and school fees). He is often confronted with difficulties in crossing over borders and the expensive costs relative to transporting cattle, but he usually manages to make the trip with other livestock-raisers from his area so as to meet these challenges. 

In future, Mamdou would like to take out a higher loan amount to develop his livestock-raising activity and earn more profit so that he can buy a residential plot in town and then build on it for his family.

loans.use: buy cattle feed to fatten his oxen and then resell them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase soybeans to make Soumbala

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 33 years old. He is married with 4 children aged 2 to 9 years. Two of them go to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 15 years, while his wife owns a business. With the loan from Kiva he will pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be uses to pay school fees of his children and to improve his savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow to enable her to supply milk to her clients and also buy farm inputs and increase her agricultural produce.

loans.name: Callixte

texts.en:
Callixte, age 42, is a maize farmer. He has been engaged in this work for 20 years. He and his wife, who is also a farmer, have five children between the ages of eight and 16 years old. All five children attend school.

With his loan from Kiva, Callixte would like to pay workers to help him harvest his maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay the school fees of his children and to improve his family's welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers to help him harvest his maize

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en: Zurab is 64 years old. He is divorced and lives alone in a small village in Gori district. Zurab wants to open an enterprise where he will produce soy dairy products. He has already purchased the equipment needed for production, and he needs money for soy. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase soy for production. Zurab will work hard in his newly opened enterprise, and he plans to expand the business in the future.

loans.use: to open a soy dairy products enterprise

loans.name: Celestine

texts.en: Celestina is a 38 year-old, married woman with one dependent child. She sells foodstuff, women’s wear and wax prints. She has been doing this for nine years from door-to-door. She needs a loan to buy slippers, rice, sugar, milk, milo, tinned tomatoes, diapers and tilapia to sell to customers. The profits will be used to pay for household expenses and to help pay for her child's education. She became a member of ID-Ghana in 2012 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: To buy slippers, rice, sugar, milk, milo, tinned tomatoes, diapers and tilapia to sell to customers.

loans.name: Sreymom's Group

texts.en: Sreymom, a farmer living in Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, is 40 years old and the mother of two children. Both of her children are dependent on her and still in school. She struggles for a living via selling vegetables, pork, and fish at the market nearby her house. Sometimes, she works for others for a fee to supplement her income. For Sreymom, this is her third time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and she fully repaid her past loans. In this group of three, she is the group leader. She will spend her loan portion to buy a Tuk-Tuk, a three-wheel motorcycle, to support her business. She hopes that she can expand her business to earn more income to improve her family’s living to be better than before.

loans.use: to buy a Tuk-Tuk, a three-wheel motorcycle, to support her business.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 57 years old. He is married with two children, aged 6 and 23 years. They both go to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 40 years. Also, his wife is a farmer. 

With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land and to improve his welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
This is Maribel, 50, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is a widow and she, together with her children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Maribel operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries and other supplies to expand her product inventory. She will also use her loan to buy pigs and feed needed to maintain the operation of her piggery.

Maribel dreams of expanding her store to create more profit through it. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock of grocery items for her variety store and also purchase pigs and feed needed for her piggery.

loans.name: Anastase

texts.en:
Anastase is 29 years old. He is married. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for 18 years. Also his wife is a farmer. 

With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a cow and to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee, age 28, is a maize farmer. She has been engaged in this activity for six years. She and her husband, who has his own business, have one child, age five. The child attends school.

With her loan from Kiva, Immaculee would like to pay workers who helped her to harvest her maize. The profits from the business will be used to improve her family's welfare. 

Immaculee's goal is to buy a house for her family to live in.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who helped her to harvest her maize

loans.name: Stellah

texts.en:
Stellah, age 47, has been engaged in mixed farming for the past 18 years. She earns her income through growing and harvesting maize, cabbage, and tomatoes, and also by keeping dairy cows. She lives with her four children in Chegoria, a remote village in the Chuka region.

Stellah is elegant and admirable in spirit and effort. She is a role model in her community, serving as a mentor and an inspiration to many young farmers in her village because of her resilience despite personal challenges. She is particularly admired for her passion in supporting her four children as their primary caregiver. Stellah's ambition is to consistently provide nutritious food for her family.

Stellah is requesting a loan to buy an additional dairy cow. This is not just an ordinary cow, but a quality breed of dairy cow that will be producing between 10 and 20 liters of milk each day. This will immediately translate to better profits and increased income levels. Stellah's profits from selling milk will be used toward repaying the loan in full, and the extra income will be used to increase her business enterprise. Stellah is very visionary, and her goal for the near future is to start adding value to her milk business by packaging the milk before selling it. She will also start selling dairy products such as yogurt. 

An improved income level will assure Stellah's family of a secure future. By joining Juhudi Kilimo, which assists smallholder farmers, she will also benefit from free extension services and links to markets. Stellah believes that if female farmers had the same access to resources as men, the number of the world's hungry could be reduced by half.

loans.use: To buy a quality dairy cow

loans.name: Anastasie

texts.en:
Anastasie is aged 46 years. She is married with five children aged between 2 and 19 years. Three of them go to school. 

She is a farmer, and she has been growing maize for 28 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. 

The profits from the business will be used to pay the school fees of her children and to renovate her house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Aleqsandre

texts.en:
Aleqsandre is 32 years old. He is married and lives with his wife and mother in Ozurgeti district. 

Aleqsandre owns a commercial space and gets monthly rent. He wants to build another commercial space and he started building, but does not have enough money to finish it. 

The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of 2,800 USD. With the received credit, he will finish the building and will rent it out, which will give him additional income. 

With increased income Aleqsandre will be able to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to build a commercial space in order to rent it out and generate additional income

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 48 years old and single. She works hard to improve her business. 

She runs a provision business in Ghana, and requested a GHS 1,200 loan through ID-Ghana to purchase more rice, sugar, can food, noodles, soap, sanitary pads etc. to sell to customers. 

Elizabeth has borrowed and repaid two loans from ID-Ghana before this loan. She has been running this business for six years. 

Elizabeth aspires to save enough money so she can afford to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, sugar, can food, noodles, soap, sanitary pads etc. to sell to customers.

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste is 28 years old. He is married. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past eight years. His wife is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 39 years old. He is married with two children. He has had a construction supplies business for five years. 

He will be using the loan to purchase construction materials and hopes this will help him to pay school fees for his children. His hopes and dreams for the future are to improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to help him to pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Mkhitar

texts.en:
Mkhitar greatly thanks lenders for his two Kiva loans. He will be happy if Kiva lenders support him one more time.  Mkhitar lives with his large family in the village of Zovaber in Gegharkunik region (he lives with his wife, three children, and his retired mother). In his farm Mkhitar breeds  cows, sheep, lambs and chickens and he sell milk, meat and eggs to his customers from Sevan city. His agricultural activities make up the main part of his family income; on his plot of land he grows potatoes and greens, which he sells right from his house to re-sellers. 

Mkhitar will be so thankful for his third Kiva loan which he plans to use for the purchase of potato seedlings, fertilizer, diesel fuel, and fodder for his livestock.

loans.use: for the purchase of potato seedlings, fertilizer, diesel fuel, and fodder for his cattle

loans.name: Gifsie

texts.en:
This is Gifsie, 41, a resident of Bagong Silang, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Allan and they have children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Gifsie operates a computer rental shop. In the Philippines, very few people own their own computers. Thus there is a need for them, especially for students who need to do their research and papers. Gifsie rents out computers by the hour and offers printing and typing services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to pay for maintenance and buy spare parts and accessories needed in her business. She is also into buying and selling rice, dried fish and charcoal. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Gifsie dreams to grow her business more and be able to help her relatives and friends who are in need. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for maintenance and buy spare parts needed in her computer rental business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Sonia Mercedes

texts.es:
Sonia tiene 36 años, tiene 2 hijos, está separada, vive en casa familiar en el sector de la Gangotena que pertenece a Antonio Ante de Imbabura, lugar donde hay turismo como los volcanes de Imbabura, Cotacachi, cuicocha y también lugares como la laguna de yahuarcocha, san pablo y otros lugares más que son visitados por miles de turistas.
Sonia tiene su local de comida rápida en su domicilio ella viene realizando esta actividad más de 3 años y le va muy bien a pesar de lo duro de la vida, después de la separación del marido le ha tocado sacar adelante a sus hijos dándoles educación, bienestar en el hogar. Luchó bastante para seguir adelante en la vida y hoy en día es una persona que sigue demostrando todo lo mejor en su negocio y demostrando ser un ejemplo para sus hijos. Con las ganancias de su negocio ha podido hacer muchas cosas en el hogar como comprar artefactos, en un futuro quiere comprar un terreno  y tener una vivienda propia para su familia.
El crédito que solicita lo va invertir en la compra de mesas, sillas, cocina nueva para el negocio, y así mejorar el local y seguir atendiendo a más clientes.
texts.en:
Sonia is 36 years old, has two children, is separated, and lives in a house in La Gangotena area. This area is part of the Antonio Ante de Imbabura canton, a region where there are tourist attractions such as the Imbabura, Cotacachi, and Cuicocha volcanoes; the Yahuarcocha and San Pablo lakes; and other places that draw thousands of tourists.

Sonia set up her fast-food stall at her home. She has been running her business for more than three years, and she is doing very well in spite of life's hardships. After separating from her husband, she had to provide for her children, their education, and their well-being at home. 

She worked very hard to move on with her life, and, today, she is a person who keeps on doing her utmost for her business and showing that she is a role model for her children. 

With the profits from her business, she has been able to buy many things for her home. In the future, she wants to buy a plot of land and have her own family home.

She is requesting a loan to buy tables, chairs, and a new stove for her business so that she can improve the place and serve more customers.

loans.use: to buy tables, chairs, and a new stove for the business.

loans.name: Zulekhan

texts.en:
Zulekhan  is 45 years old, a married woman and a mother of five children. She is working hard to fulfill their needs, including food, health care, clothing, and education.   With her husband (also shown in the photo) she has been doing work in agriculture for some years. They grow different vegetables and fruits and sell them in the local market.  

Zulekhan has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation. In order to purchase different types of seeds with packs of insecticides and pesticides, Zulekhan  has currently  applied for a loan of 30,000 PKR. This would help her to grow more crops which ultimately help in generating more cash.

loans.use: to purchase different types of seeds with packs of insecticides and pesticides

loans.name: Saeda

texts.en:
Saeda was born in 1976. She is single and lives in Jabal Alhussien. She lost her parents many years ago and she lives alone, Saeda was an upset, lonely and sad lady, but her friends and neighbors did not hesitate to support her to start a new life and they did not fail, Saeda decided to start a new life and be a productive woman. The first thing was to run a small business with a small quantity of clothes and blankets to sell.  

Now Saeda needs to expand her business by purchasing a larger quantity of clothes and to add accessories to her sales in order to raise her profit and to open her own store. But she doesn't have enough money to do that, therefore she has applied for this loan to buy more products to sell and increase her income.
She needs your help and support to achieve her dreams to be one of the productive women in the word.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell and increase her income

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 29 years old. He is married with one child, aged one year old. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 10 years, while his wife is a businesswoman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to build a house and to improve their welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en:
Sumaira  is 35 years old; she is a married woman.  She deals in a business selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices, brings them up, and then sells them out in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. She also sells milk to generate an extra amount of income. 

Sumaira needs to improve her business to cover her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 30,000  to purchase more animals to grow her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income level.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to grow her sales.

loans.name: Sogharn

texts.en: Sogharn is 39 years old and married.  She deals in the business of selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats & calves) at low prices, brings them up and then sells them out in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute in the family income. She also sells milk to generate an extra income. She needs to improve her business to bear her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied a loan of PKR 40000 to purchase more animals to increase her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan she will definitely expand her business and income level.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to increase her sales.

loans.name: Taw Ku West Village (Group 4)

texts.en:
This group of borrowers, Taw Ku West Village Group 4, are farmers. Pictured here from left to right, their names are Kyaw, Htay, Khin, Aye and Swe. They are Community Based Organization members, and are a part of the larger Taw Ku West Village group, which comprises over 600 households in the Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy Delta region. They lead a group of thirty village customers.

Rice farming is the main activity in this village. This loan will help some members of this group purchase fertilizers and petrol, as well as to hire laborers. Additional income generated from these loans will help build secondary businesses for some villagers, such as starting up in-house grocery shops, planting seasonal vegetables, and raising livestock. For example, one loan can help farmers buy petrol for irrigating a five-acre paddy field for a month, or for paying laborers for a month.  

Htay, age 41, pictured second from the left, is a farmer. She and her husband are blessed with two children, the youngest of whom attends eighth grade. The eldest son has to help the family business in order to ease the family's financial difficulties and to support his brother's education. 

This family has a 10-acre crop farm, on which they farm rice in rice paddies. For additional income, they also have a small in-house grocery stand. Htay plans to use her loan funds to buy petrol and other necessary inputs, as well as to hire laborers. With the additional income expected, Htay intends to expand her business as well as save money toward her son's education fees.

Proximity's low interest rate is very important to Htay because she does not think she could survive in the long run with higher interest rates from other lending groups.

loans.use: to purchase crop inputs such as petrol and fertilizer, as well as to hire laborers

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
Bushra, age 38, and her husband are buyers and sellers of livestock. They have been engaged in this work for many years, and the business has provided their family with a decent life. Bushra is the mother of seven children. She is very motivated to provide them with as positive a life as she possibly can, including nutritious food, quality clothing, and access to a good education. 

Bushra has requested a loan in the amount of 45,000 PKR. She intends to utilize her loan funds to purchase calves and baby goats so that she can cater to more customers. 

Her goal is to see her business generate greater revenues in the future.

loans.use: to purchase calves and baby goats

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza, age 34, earns her living by operating a sari-sari (variety store) business. A sari-sari is a small store that can be owned by anyone in the community, and the store is either connected to or located just inside their houses. This is where you can buy such individual items as a sachet of shampoo or conditioner, a bar of soap, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Analiza gets her products from a wholesaler at a lower price, then sells items per piece for a higher price to attain a profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors, passers-by, and members of her community. She earns about PhP 1,000 per day.

Analiza lives in Caloocan City with her husband Jonas, who is a factory worker. God has blessed them with children, all of whom attend school. Life is hard for Jonas and Alaliza, but by the grace of God they have found themselves able to raise their children well, and they help each other in supporting their family.

In order to be able to expand her inventory, Analiza is requesting a loan in the amount of PhP 23,000. She will use her loan funds to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages with which to expand her product inventory. The loan will be a great help to her, allowing her to add a greater quantity and variety of products to her store. Her goal is to see her business continue to grow, and she is determined to gain more regular customers. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, as well as to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages with which to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Manar

texts.en: Manar is a 32-year-old married mother of four children who are attending school. She has been working since six years ago from her house selling homemade food in order to help her family to meet their needs of life and living in a good way. Today, Manar is asking a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to improve her business merchandise and to give the best product to her clients and therefore increase her income. She is very happy and optimistic that she will sell all the products and expand her business area. She hopes that in the future she might open her own store and attract more customers.

loans.use: improve her food business

loans.name: Arsen

texts.en:
Arsen lives in the frontier village Achajur in the Tavush region. Arsen here lives with his wife (she is a housewife), two children (school-aged) and his retired mother.  

For many years and until today Arsen has done different construction work on order and he combines it with farming and agriculture for income. He is especially engaged in swine breeding. He mentions that he works with city butchers, who buy his farm’s meat for many years. He also has a large plot of land on which he cultivates vegetables (potato, cucumber, carrot, cabbage, greens, etc.) and fruits (apple, fig, grapes, persimmon, peach, nuts and mulberry).   

Arsen works all day long in his farm but he also finds time to take his farm products to the city’s wholesale market for sale. All the income from farming goes for his family’s financial needs, especially for the care and needs of his school-aged children. Arsen hopes that his first Kiva deal will be very profitable both for his farm and his family.  So he decided by the help of this loan to develop swine breeding on his farm -- he will buy several piglets and also animal fodder for his pigs.

loans.use: buy piglets & fodder

loans.name: Varantsov

texts.en:
Varantsov is 40 years old and he lives with his big and lovely family in the village Ddmashen in the Gegharkunik region. Varantsov has three children:  two boys and a pretty girl. Varantsov’s wife is unemployed and she takes care of their children and equally with her husband works on their farm. Since 1994 until today Varantsov has been the shepherd of their village. He likes his work despite of its great risk and responsibility, since for any peasant family farm cattle are the greatest treasure and they trust all of it to him. Varantsov is responsible of the security and return for the animals from the pastures to their barns at the end of each day. 

On his farm, Varantsov has horses, cows, calves, bulls, sheep and chickens. His wife makes perfect cheese and macun (national dairy-product) and she sells it with milk and eggs, mainly to her neighbors and regular customers. For this man, farming is the only source of income and he dreams of providing his family with better living thanks to its development.   With this loan of 400,000 Armenian drams Varantsov  plans to buy 2 more calves and also animal fodder for his farm cattle.

loans.use: buy calves & fodder

loans.name: Alvard

texts.en:
This woman is 46 years old and lives in the village of Tsovagyugh in the  Gegharkunik region. Her name is Alvard and she lives with her husband, who works as a welder, and a single son of 27 years old (unemployed).  This family’s income is from farming and they all work very hard to make more profit from  it.  

On her farm Alvard has cows, bulls, sheep, pigs, a horse and chickens. Alavrd takes care of them, breeds them and arranges all the work connected with her farm cattle with the help of her son. From her farm she sells milk, cheese, meat and eggs. Land cultivation is also not hard work for this woman. On her plot of land she grows potato, greens, tomato and cucumber.  She sells her harvests at the city’s wholesale market during the week.   

With this loan amount of 700,000 Armenian drams, Alavrd wants to enlarge her farm and arrange her land cultivation activities -- she will buy a calf, fertilizer and also animal fodder for her farm cattle.

loans.use: buy a calf, fertilizer & fodder

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
From Caloocan City, Susan has been an active member of CCT for years now and she was able to acquire several loans to make a good profit from her business. At the age of 52, Susan still manages to operate her business and makes good profit through it. Her business is helping her to provide for her family's daily needs. She works hard every day and she is pretty sure that she is closer to reaching her goals.

Susan owns a variety store. She believes that business is her stepping stone toward making her dreams happen. She knows how important it is for her neighbors and daily consumers to have a nearby store where they can buy a sachet of shampoo, a bar of soap, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, an egg, toothpaste or even ice cube. She gets her product from a wholesaler at a lower price then she sells it per piece for a higher price to have profit.

Susan desires to manage a bigger store someday, so she is requesting a PHP 13,000 loan, which she will use to buy additional groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She also looks forward to seeing her children finish their studies through all her hard work and perseverance.

Susan meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: restock her store

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna successfully paid back her first Kiva loan and hopes that she will manage to receive more loans. She lives in Tsovagyugh village in the Gegharkunik region. She farms and breeds animals on her own plot of land. Anna is mainly alone in all farming activities since her husband is still abroad in Russia for work, her son is still a student and has not enough time to help his mother about the farm, and her daughter is married and lives with her family. 

Anna breeds cows, sheep and chickens on her farm and sells her farm products to her regular customers from Sevan city. In addition to farming she also works as a nurse at the outpatient clinic. On her plot of land she grows potatoes since it is the most profitable vegetable for sale in the region where she lives.  Anna needs this loan in order to buy potato seedlings, diesel fuel and fertilizer for her land and also fodder for her farm cattle.

loans.use: buy potato seedlings, diesel & animal fodder

loans.name: Shabana

texts.en: Shabana  is a 23-year-old married woman. She is a mother of 3 children. She  has been doing a business of animal sale and purchase for many years along with her husband. Shabana is keen to provide her family with good standard of living. Now, she has requested for a loan of 30000 PKR. She wants to use this loan amount  to purchase more cattle for reselling in the market. She desires of improving her standard of living thorough all her efforts.

loans.use: buy livestock

loans.name: Naeem

texts.en:
Naeem is a 41-year-old married woman and mother of 5 children. She is working hard to fulfill their demands, including food, health, clothing, and education.  She with her husband (also shown in the photo) have been doing work of agriculture for some years. They farm different vegetables and fruits and sell them in the local market.  Naeem has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation. 

In order to purchase different types of seeds with packs of insecticides and pesticides, Naeem has applied for a loan of 35000 PKR. This would help her to grow more crops, which will ultimately help in generating more cash.

loans.use: buy seeds & insecticides

loans.name: Shah Jahan

texts.en:
Shah Jahan is 45 years old.  She is a married woman and mother of 2 children.  She is a hardworking mother who is helping her family by providing tailoring services in her community. She has been doing it for many years. She very well knows the techniques of stitching. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns enough to lead a decent life. 

To help her continue the operations of her business, Shah Jahan requested for a loan of 45000 PKR  to buy stitching materials such as spools of threads in different colors, packs of zippers and buttons, etc. to sew more dresses on time. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en:
Tahira  is a 58-year-old married woman. She has been involved in the business of cloth trading. She purchases variety of cloth at low prices from the city market and sells them in her own town. She has a strong customer base. 

Tahira  has requested for a loan of 60000 PKR. She wants  to buy greater variety of cloth in different colors for her business to get boost in her earnings with this loan.

loans.use: buy cloth to sell

loans.name: Taw Ku West Village (Group-3)

texts.en:
Taw Ku West Village (group-3) is located in the Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy Delta region. Taw Ku West has a population of approximately 2,500. The group has five female CBO (Community Based Organization) members, overseeing a group of 30 village customers. 

Rice farming is the main activity in this village. This loan will help some group members purchase fertilizers and petrol and to hire laborers. Also, additional income generated from these loans will help build secondary businesses for some villagers, such as in-house grocery shops, planting seasonal vegetables, and raising livestock. For example, one loan can help farmers buy petrol for irrigating a 5-acre paddy field for a month, or for paying laborers for a month.  

Pictured above are the CBO members from Taw Ku West Village group, named (from left to right) Myint, Mar, Khin, San, and Khin T. 

San, second from the right, is part of a family that has farmed for generations. She is proud to be a farmer because farmers are respected in Myanmar, and she uses her income to support her family's livelihood. San uses income to pay for her children's educations. San has three children, a 5-year-old child, a university student, and another attending seaman school. 

Before Proximity, San has borrowed loans from informal money lenders at high interest rates. A loan from Proximity will help San grow her income and then expand her farm business. San also plans to use income for the continued education of her two youngest children.

loans.use: To purchase crop fertilizer and other farming inputs, as well as hiring laborers

loans.name: Carlos Alberto

texts.es: Carlos tiene 55 años y se dedica desde hace 10 años a la venta de zapatos y prendas de vestir para dama y caballero, dicha actividad le permite sostener la economía de su hogar. Él habita en vivienda propia desde hace 11 años, aunque actualmente vive solo apoya a sus hijos para que estudien. Carlos es un hombre muy trabajador, y desea que su negocio le brinde mejores ingresos económicos, es por ello que ha tomado la decisión de solicitar un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: pantalones, camisas, zapatos deportivos, etc., y de esta manera mejorar sus ingresos económicos y seguir apoyando a su familia.
texts.en:
Carlos is fifty five years old and for the last ten years he has worked in the sale of shoes and clothing for women and men.  This activity has allowed him to support the economy of his home.  He has lived in his own home for eleven years.  Although he presently lives alone, he supports his children so that they can study.  

Carlos is a very hard working man.  He hopes that his business will bring him more income, which is why he has decided to solicit a loan from FUSAI to invest in:  pants, shirts, athletic shoes, etc.  In this way he plans to increase his earnings and continue supporting his family.

loans.use: To invest in pants, shirts, athletic shoes, etc.

loans.name: Speciose

texts.en:
Speciose is aged 58 years. She is married with four children aged between 12 and 28 years. They all go to school. 

She is a farmer, and she has been growing maize for 30 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. 

The profits from the business will be used to pay the school fees of her children and to improve her savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a fifty-one-year-old married woman who is taking care of four children and has been operating her farming business for a period of 12 years, making a monthly income of KES. 4,000 at the end of every month.  


This is her second loan of KES. 20,000 with VisionFund Kenya and she intends to purchase fertilizer and seeds for planting.

Veronica intends to use her anticipated profits to buy a dairy cow and hopes to be a successful farmer with a bright future.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for planting

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak lives with his nice wife and two children in the village Tsovagyugh of Gegharkunik region. He has vocational education and he likes to say if there is something about which he knows nearly everything it is farming. He has been in farming for 15 years already  and in his farm he takes care of six cows, a bull, a heifer and sheep. From his farm he mainly sells milk and meat (beef and mutton). He also has a nice orchard where he has apple, fig and apricot trees and together with his wife,  he sells these fruits at the wholesale market. 

Artak mentions that for him meat selling is very profitable and he wants to buy some more cattle for his farm and in this way expand the quantity of meat that he sells. 

He will use this loan of 700,000 Armenian drams  for the purchase of two more cows for his farm.

loans.use: to purchase two more cows for his farm

loans.name: Magret

texts.en:
Magret is thirty-six years old. She is a married woman and they have one child. She operates a restaurant business which she has done for twelve years. Her monthly income is 12,000 Kenya shillings.


This is Magret's first loan with VisionFund Kenya LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to purchase utensils for her hotel. She plans to use the profits to pay school fees for their child. Her future aspiration is to be able to provide well for her child.

loans.use: To buy utensils for the restaurant

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Antonio tiene 46 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, vive con sus 06 hijos y su cónyuge en el distrito de Pucará el cual es un distrito mediano cuyas actividades principales son el comercio y la agricultura, distrito mediano con aspiraciones a superarse que se encuentra ubicado en la provincia de Jaén, región de Cajamarca, en la sierra norte de Perú.

El se dedica a la agricultura, cuenta con una finca de café propia, esta actividad la viene realizando hace más de 20 años por lo que cuenta con experiencia en el negocio y con buenas referencias personales y laborales en su distrito. Adicionalmente se dedica a brindar servicios como peón agrícola en los diferentes cultivos de su distrito y zonas cercanas. El destino del crédito será para invertir en en la compra de abonos y fertilizantes para el mantenimiento de su finca de café, así espera lograr una mejor producción para que mejoren sus ingresos y por ende su calidad de vida y la de su familia
texts.en:
Antonio is forty six years old, in a common law marriage.  He lives with his six children and his spouse in the Pucara district which is a medium sized district whose main activities are commerce and agriculture.  This district has hopes to better itself.  It is located in the province of Jaen, the region of Cajamarca, in the north sierra of Peru.

He dedicates himself to agriculture, depending on his own coffee farm.  This activity has been realized over twenty years of experience in the business and good references, personal as well as professional, in his district.  Additionally he dedicates himself to provide services as an agricultural worker in the different crops of his district and nearby zones.  The purpose of the loan will be to invest in the purchase of compost and fertilizers for the maintenance of his coffee farm.  He hopes to achieve better production in order to increase his income and the quality of his life and that of his family as well.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of compost and fertilizer for the maintenance of his coffee farm.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase children's clothes and incense and to resell them in her community as a door-to-door salesperson.

loans.name: Mtvarisa

texts.en:
Mtvarisa is 42 years old, from the village of Bashi. She has a husband, two sons and a daughter. The family-members are temporarily unemployed, as there is a high unemployment rate in the region and also because of having no university degree or any professional education. 

Mtvarisa and her family live in poverty and get social assistance from the local government. For satisfying just the basic needs of her family, Mtvarisa is involved in agricultural business. She is engaged in cattle breeding, in cultivating a plot of agricultural land, where she harvests maize and sells it seasonally. 

As the family finds it hard to earn a living, Mtvarisa decided to expand her agricultural business and requested a loan. All the financial institutions rejected her loan request, because of their unstable financial situation. The start-up program that was created between Kiva and Credo enabled her to get a loan of 1,200 GEL and purchase watermelon seeds. Mtvarisa will plant them and get significant seasonal income from this new business. 

The loan will be a great support to this poor family and they will appreciate Kiva lenders' help and kindness.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and start cultivating watermelon

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 41 years old and married with one child. He works hard to provide for his family. He has been running a business selling chemicals (pesticides, insecticides) in Ghana for three years. 

Peter has requested a 1,100 Ghana Cedi (GHS) loan through ID-Ghana to purchase more chemicals (pesticides, insecticides) to sell. Peter has borrowed and repaid three loans from ID-Ghana prior to this loan. 

He aspires to save enough money to be able to provide his child with higher education.

loans.use: To purchase more chemicals (pesticides, insecticide) to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in:  mamey, mango, watermelon, papaya, cucumber and jicama for wholesale.

loans.name: Claudia Fabiola

texts.es: La señora Claudia es una mujer laboriosa que a sus 32 años de edad, ha dedicado los últimos diez años de su vida a la compra-venta de gallinas de granjas. Ella viaja a los departamentos del norte del país para comprarlas y luego las comercializa en el mercado de Masaya, donde el mayor porcentaje de éstas las comercializa en pie y la otra las destaza para ofrecer de diversas maneras a la población. Es un negocio familiar ya que quienes le ayudan a comercializarlas son su esposo e hijos mayores, de esta manera les inculca los valores y responsabilidades a sus hijos, y a la vez le permite aportar con los gastos del hogar con ayuda de su familia. es el vigésimo segundo ciclo que ADIM le brinda los financiamientos y ha demostrado ser una persona responsable, cumplida con sus obligaciones y con un alto nivel de superación, el crédito actual lo solicita para la compra de canastos de gallinas en pie, con el objetivo de capitalizar su negocio y seguir mejorando las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Claudia is a hard-working woman who, at the age of 32, has dedicated the last 10 years of her life to buying and selling farm chickens. She travels to the northern departments of Nicaragua to buy and, later, sell chickens in the markets of Masaya, where the greater precentage of these are sold on foot, while the remainder are butchered and offered in diverse forms to the populace.

This is a family business; assisting in the commercialization process are her husband and older children. In this manner, the parents are teaching values and responsibilities to their children.

This is ADIM's 22nd loan cycle, offering financing, and Claudia has proven to be a responsible person, complying with her obligations and achieving a high level of advancement. This loan was requested in order to purchase baskets of standing chickens. Claudia's objective is to further capitalize her business and continue to better her family's conditions of life.

loans.use: buy hens to raise and, later, sell in the north.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to increase her income from the supply of milk

loans.name: Kadiatu J

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Kadiatu J.  She is married and has two children aged eight and four years old. One is a school-going child. She has one additional dependent, who lives with her and is fostered. Kadiatu J. owns a provisions business. Working six days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 2,060,400 SLL every month from this business. 

Kadiatu J. has already received and successfully repaid three loans, and now requires a new loan in order to buy cartons of eggs, mayonnaise, ketchup, etc. for resale. She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. 

In the future, Kadiatu J. plans to build another house for her children, to reinvest, and to expand her business. This loan will help her to maximize more profit. Her previous plans were partly met by completing her house and buying another piece of land, but she was unable to rent a shop due to the high rental cost.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy cartons of eggs, mayonnaise, ketchup, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Romik

texts.en:
Romik is 43 years old and lives with his big family in the village Davit Bek of Syunik region. Romik is a very skilled and clever farmer. His farm is rich with cattle; he has cows, calves and bulls, and he also has chickens.

From their farm, Romik’s wife sells meat, milk, cheese and macun (national dairy product similar to yogurt). Romik also has a tractor, which he uses to cultivate the land on his own farm and that of others. He fulfills orders from his fellow villagers to work on their land, and he is paid for it.

Romik also is employed; he works at the school as a warden. He has three children; his son is doing his military service in the army, and his two daughters are still school aged.

Romik hopes to receive this loan as it will help him to buy diesel fuel for his tractor for his land cultivation and also to buy animal fodder for his cattle.

loans.use: to buy diesel fuel for his tractor for his land cultivation and to buy animal fodder for his cattle

loans.name: Madoleine

texts.en:
Madoleine is aged 29 years. She is married with one child aged 9 months, not yet in school.

She is a farmer, and she has been growing maize for the past eight years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. 

The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Iragi Group

texts.fr: Madame Sombo est une femme ambitieuse et courage de l’association de crédit Iragi. Marié à un homme sans emploie, elle est âgée de 35 ans et mère de 9 enfants empruntant tous le chemin de l’école. Elle débuta les activités de petit commerce grâce au soutient de son mari avant de regagner Hekima. Elle sollicite un nouveau prêt à ce jour pour acheter 20kg de farine, 5 litres d’huile, les oignons et tomates. Son objectif pour l’avenir est de payer convenable la scolarité de ses enfants et développer son business. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour tout.
texts.en:
Madame Sombo is an ambitious and courageous woman from the loan group called Iragi. Married to a husband who is jobless, she is 35 and the mother of nine children all going to school. 

She began her small-scale business thanks to the support of her husband before she found Hekima. Today, she is asking for a new loan to buy 20 kilos of flour, 5 liters of oil, onions, and tomatoes. Her goal for the future is to pay her children's school fees appropriately and develop her business. She thanks Hekima for everything.

loans.use: to buy 20 kilos of flour, 5 liters of oil, onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Pakiso

texts.en:
Pakiso (32) lives in Freedom Park, Johannesburg.

He is married and is a father of two. Pakiso works hard to support his family, including his mother-in-law. He operates a transport business ferrying kids to and from school as well as delivering goods whenever he gets hired to. 

He is requesting a loan to buy a minivan. The van will have more capacity than his current vehicle, and he is certain that he will secure long-term contracts with schools around his neighborhood to transport children. He will also be able to provide more delivery capacity for clients wanting delivery services.

Pakiso is an ambitious man and hopes to one day own a transportation business-preferably he says in the mining sector, that will create employment.

loans.use: to buy a minivan

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is 42 years old. She is married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with seven children.

Roseline has a motorcycle transport business as her primary activity and it has been profitable. She also runs a business selling vegetables and fruits as well as charcoal.

She has requested her first loan with Vision Fund Kenya, of KES 15,000, to purchase another motorcycle and serve more customer as well as make more income to help her educate her children and provide for her family's needs.

Roseline's hopes and dreams are to have an improved standard of living as well as to bring her business to higher levels.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle and serve more customer as well as make more income to educate her children.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy up-to-date cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy poultry

loans.name: Edinah

texts.en:
Edinah is 31 years old,married with one child. She sells household goods, a business she has had for five years. 

She will be using the loan to buy kitchen utensils, water buckets, and plastic basins for sell and hopes this will enable her to get more income to educate her child and also buy a plot of land. 

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to be successful in her business and improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils, water buckets, and plastic basins for sell and hopes this will enable her to get more income to educate her child.

loans.name: Sekenet

texts.en:
Sekenet is 55 years old. She is married and has five children. She sells milk and has been in this business for 14 years.

She plans to use the loan to buy more stock of milk for selling to her customers and generate more income which will enable her to provide for the basic needs like clothes and food for her children. This is her third loan with VisionFund Kenya and she has paid her previous loans successfully.

In future she wants to expand her business and be self-sustainable

loans.use: To buy more stock of milk for selling to her customers and generate more income which will enable her to provide for the basic needs like clothes and food for her children.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is aged 44 years. He is married with six children aged between 3 and 22 years; five of them go to school. He is a farmer, and he has been growing maize for the past 19 years. Also, his wife is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay the workers who harvest maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay the school fees of his children and improve his savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay the workers who harvest maize.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 40 years old. He is married with four children. He operates a boutique and has been in the business for 13 years. His monthly income is 42,000 Kenya shillings (KES).

This is his first loan with VisionFund Kenya, LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to purchase stocks of clothing for sale. He plans to use the profits to buy dairy cows. In the future he hopes to own a wholesale shop and become a milk distributor.

loans.use: to purchase new clothes for selling.

loans.name: Nshobole Group

texts.fr: La cliente Sifa, femme dynamique est présidente du groupe de crédit Nshobole. Agée de 37 ans, elle est mariée à un cultivateur et mère de  6 enfants tous allant à l’école. Elle débuta son activité dans un de marché communal avec l’argent reçu de son mari avant de rejoindre Hekima. A ce jour, elle sollicite un nouveau credit pour acheter 40kg de farine et payer le transport. Son objectif est d’affecter les fruits de ce prêt au payement de frais scolaires des enfants et agrandir son entreprise. Au final, elle remercie grandement Hekima pour son soutien.
texts.en:
Our client Sifa, an energetic person, is the leader of the Nshobole borrowers’ group. She is 37 years old, married to a farmer and has six children, all of whom are in school. She launched her business at the community market with the funds received from her husband, and later joined Hekima. 

At present she is seeking a new loan to buy 40 kg [88 lbs] of flour and pay delivery costs. Her goal is to use the revenues from this loan to pay her children’s school fees and grow her business. In conclusion, Sifa expresses heartfelt thanks to Hekima for its support.

loans.use: to buy 40 kg of flour and pay delivery costs.

loans.name: Musafili

texts.en:
Musafili is 27 years old. He is married with three children aged between 1 and 4 years, one of whom goes to school. He is a farmer, while his wife is a business woman. He has been growing maize for the past eight years.

With the loan from Kiva, Musafili would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Matiya

texts.en:
Matiya is 41 years and lives in Kasese, Uganda, with his wife and five children. 

He  used the previous loan to buy sugar, salt, cassava, flour, and other general merchandise to sell.  He managed to use the proceeds to meet his family obligations and re-invest in his business. 

As he plans for the Easter season, he would like to buy more stock so that he can increase his sales during this peak season. 
He is requesting a loan to buy soda, cooking oil,sugar, salt, cassava flour and other general merchandise to sell.

loans.use: to buy soda, cooking oil,sugar, salt, cassava flour and other general merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Slivestre

texts.en:
Slivestre is 35 years old. He is married with four children aged between one and nine years. One of them goes to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 14 years.
